head.title: The New Frontier, in the Heart of the City

hedline.hl1: The New Frontier, in the Heart of the City

abstract.p: Elizabeth Grossman letter on Nov 23 article holds attention to urban ecology should not be used as excuse to abandon efforts to preserve wilderness; drawing

block.p: In ''Wild Cities: It's a Jungle Out There'' (Arts & Ideas, Nov. 23), the coordinator of Columbia University and Unesco's program on the biosphere and society says: ''The choice is no longer between cities and wildness. It is, in the face of increasing population, between density and sprawl.''

In ''Wild Cities: It's a Jungle Out There'' (Arts & Ideas, Nov. 23), the coordinator of Columbia University and Unesco's program on the biosphere and society says: ''The choice is no longer between cities and wildness. It is, in the face of increasing population, between density and sprawl.''
While density does indeed help preserve open space, an increasing population, whether in single-family homes or apartment towers, will consume an increasing amount of natural resources.

Attention to urban ecology -- prompted in part by the effects of global warming -- is undeniably important, but it should not be used as an excuse to abandon efforts to preserve those wildlands and roadless areas that remain or to stabilize population.
Nor should learning about the evolving biodiversity of cities allow us to simply accept global warming as something over which we have no control.
